articles.headline: Budget Battles Keep Agencies Guessing
articles.snippet: The combination of cuts and a breakdown in the budgeting process leaves offices reluctant to hire or to commit to big projects.
articles.abstract: The combination of cuts and a breakdown in the budgeting process leaves offices reluctant to hire or to commit to big projects.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The collision of the $1 trillion in budget cuts known as sequestration and the breakdown of the normal budgeting process is creating headaches not just for Washington but also for a vast web of offices dependent on federal financing. Many have been left uncertain as to how much money — if any — they will have to spend in the year ahead.

articles.headline: Someday Worth Billions, but Now, They Need a Desk
articles.snippet: As tech start-ups push demand for office space in San Francisco, RocketSpace is responding with long tables, Internet access and rules against getting too big.
articles.abstract: As tech start-ups push demand for office space in San Francisco, RocketSpace is responding with long tables, Internet access and rules against getting too big.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In the 20th-century workplace, Duncan Logan might be considered an abusive landlord. He rents working spaces without doors or walls between tenants. Instead, his renters work at long tables, and sometimes those tables are shared with other companies.

articles.headline: No Bounce for Europe in Rebound by Germany
articles.snippet: The crisis has weakened ties in the euro zone as German companies, with the government cheering them on, look to China and the United States.
articles.abstract: The crisis has weakened ties in the euro zone as German companies, with the government cheering them on, look to China and the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Whenever Germany thrived, so did the rest of Europe. But that long-held belief is being questioned by its neighbors, which see evidence that the country is taking off without them.

articles.headline: Business Losing Clout in a G.O.P. Moving Right
articles.snippet: Scholars have proposed many reasons for the diminished role businesses have with Congressional Republicans, and, yes, it’s about money.
articles.abstract: Scholars have proposed many reasons for the diminished role businesses have with Congressional Republicans, and, yes, it’s about money.
articles.lead_paragraph: How did corporate America lose control of the Republican Party?

articles.headline: In Nokia, Microsoft Bets on Apple-Like Revival
articles.snippet: Microsoft’s predicament recalls the situation Apple found itself in during the early 1990s, with high-quality products overlooked in the marketplace.
articles.abstract: Microsoft’s predicament recalls the situation Apple found itself in during the early 1990s, with high-quality products overlooked in the marketplace.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — With its purchase of Nokia’s phone business, Microsoft is taking inspiration from Apple’s way of making products, bringing hardware and software under a single roof where they can be more elegantly woven together.

articles.headline: Shedding Handsets, Nokia Looks to the Future
articles.snippet: Nokia, despite the sale of its handset unit to Microsoft, will still be in business with two major technology components: networking and mapping.
articles.abstract: Nokia, despite the sale of its handset unit to Microsoft, will still be in business with two major technology components: networking and mapping.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nokia, which began making rubber boots for Finnish workmen 150 years ago and was an innovative leader of the cellphone industry in the 1990s, is once again evolving.
articles.byline: By Mark Scott and Brian X. Chen

articles.headline: Errors Cast Doubt on Japan’s Cleanup of Nuclear Accident Site
articles.snippet: Analysts are questioning whether Japan’s government and the operator of the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant have the expertise and ability to manage the crisis.
articles.abstract: Analysts are questioning whether Japan’s government and the operator of the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant have the expertise and ability to manage the crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: NARAHA, Japan — In this small farming town in the evacuation zone surrounding the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, small armies of workers in surgical masks and rubber gloves are busily scraping off radioactive topsoil in a desperate attempt to fulfill the central government’s vow one day to allow most of Japan’s 83,000 evacuees to return. Yet, every time it rains, more radioactive contamination cascades down the forested hillsides along the rugged coast.

articles.headline: Bar Mitzvahs Get New Look to Build Faith
articles.snippet: American Jews often view the coming-of-age ceremony not as an entry to Jewish life, but as a graduation ceremony. A new initiative by the Reform movement is out to change that.
articles.abstract: American Jews often view the coming-of-age ceremony not as an entry to Jewish life, but as a graduation ceremony. A new initiative by the Reform movement is out to change that.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The American bar mitzvah, facing derision for Las Vegas style excess, is about to get a full makeover, but for an entirely different reason.

articles.headline: Assad Wages War Shielded With a Smile
articles.snippet: President Bashar al-Assad’s public activities mask increasing aggression in battle and belie fears among many supporters of an American attack.
articles.abstract: President Bashar al-Assad’s public activities mask increasing aggression in battle and belie fears among many supporters of an American attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria appeared to be in a jovial mood late last week, even while facing a threatened American attack, joking with a visiting Yemeni delegation about the political mess in nearby Egypt and deriding his regional rivals as “half men.”
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Ben Hubbard
